facts.text: Employee Bhanu Bala joined the appellant's service in 1929.

anchor.surface_text: The said employee had joined the appellants service in 1929 but there was a break in the companytinuity of his service

facts.text: Break in continuity of Bhanu Bala's service for nearly 81 months from February 14, 1945 to the end of October, 1945 due to absence without permission or leave.

facts.text: Resignation submitted by appellant's employee Bhanu Bala was accepted by the appellant on August 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1957, resignation submitted by the appellants employee Bhanu Bala was accepted by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant offered Rs. 1,165 and odd to Bhanu Bala on compassionate grounds.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant the said employee was number entitled to any gratuity under the scheme framed by the award. Even so the appellant offered him Rs. 1,165

facts.text: Industrial dispute led to application by employee before First Labour Court at Bombay under s. 33C of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The demand thus made by the employee led to an industrial dis- pute which was taken by the employee before the First Labour Court at Bombay under s. 33C of the Act.

facts.text: Labour Court decided in favour of the employee and directed appellant to pay Rs. 1,781-80 nP. as gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court entertained the application, decided the point in dispute in favour of the employee and directed the appellant to pay him Rs. 1,781-80 nP. as gratuity.

arguments.claim: Continuous service in context of gratuity scheme postulates continuance of master-servant relationship; breaks by resignation, employer termination, operation of law; mere unauthorised absence or illegal strike does not break continuity unless properly terminated or abandonment inferred from prolonged absence.

anchor.surface_text: Continuous service in the context of the scheme of gratuity framed by the tribunal in the earlier reference postulates the continuance of the relationship of master and servant

holdings.text: The meaning attributed to the words 'continuous service' in the context of the Factories Act may not have a material bearing in deciding the point in the present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As this Court has observed in Budge Budge Municipality v. P. R. Mukherjee 2 , the same words may mean one thing in one context and another in different context. This is the reason why decisions on the meaning of particular words or collection of words found in other statutes are scarcely of 1 1953 S.C.R. 219. 2 1953 1 L. L. J. 195, 198. much value when we have to deal with a specific statute of our own they may be helpful but cannot be taken as guides or precedents. Therefore, the meaning attributed to the words continuous service in the context of the Factories Act may not have a material bearing in deciding the point in the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words have context-dependent meanings; decisions interpreting terms in Factories Act provisions (s.49B, s.79) and related cases like Buckingham not binding precedents for award interpretation.

holdings.text: The operation of the statutory definition of 'continuous service' in s.2(eee) of the Industrial Disputes Act cannot be automatically extended to interpret the term in an industrial award unless justified by the award's context.

anchor.surface_text: This definition is undoubtedly relevant in dealing with the question of continuous service by reference to the provisions of Industrial Disputes Act but its operation cannot be automatically extended in dealing with an interpretation of the words continuous service in an award made in an industrial dispute unless the context in which the expression is used in the award justifies it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions apply to their own Act; awards must be interpreted on their principles unless they adopt or context justifies statutory meaning.

holdings.text: 'Continuous service' in the gratuity scheme postulates continuance of master-servant relationship, broken by resignation, employer termination, or operation of law; mere unauthorised absence or illegal strike does not automatically break it unless properly terminated or abandonment inferred.

anchor.surface_text: Continuous service in the context of the scheme of gratuity framed by the tribunal in the earlier reference postulates the continuance of the relationship of master and servant between the employer and his employees. If the servant resigns his employment service automatically comes to an end. If the employer terminates the service, of his employee that again brings the continuity of service to an end. If the service of an employee is brought to an end by the operation of any law that again is another instance where the continuance is disrupted but it is difficult to hold that merely because an employee is absent without obtaining leave that itself would bring to an end the continuity of his service. Similarly, participation in an illegal strike which may incur the punishment of dismissal may not by itself bring to an end the relationship of master and ser- vant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation based on gratuity scheme context; continuity tied to ongoing master-servant relation, not disrupted by temporary absences without formal end.

holdings.text: Long unauthorised absence for such period that inference of abandonment of service may reasonably be drawn legitimately causes a break in continuity of service.

anchor.surface_text: It may be a good cause for the termination of service provided of course the relevant provisions in the standing orders in that behalf are complied with but mere participation in an illegal strike cannot be said to cause breach in continuity for the purposes of gratuity. On the other hand, if an employee continues to be absent from duty without obtaining leave and in an unauthorised manner for such a long period of time that an inference may reasonably be drawn from such absence that by his absence he has aban- doned service, then such long unauthorised absence may legitimately be held to cause a break in the continuity of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes mere absence/illegal strike from prolonged absence implying abandonment; factual inference determines break.

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal's interpretation of 'continuous service' as service not broken by termination of contract by employer, employee or operation of law is substantially right, modified to include breaks inferred from long unauthorised absence implying abandonment; award confirmed, appeal dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantially adopts tribunal's textual interpretation, adds abandonment modification based on master-servant continuance principle; applies to facts rejecting break claim.

The fact of nearly 81 months absence without permission or leave triggers the concept that long unauthorised absence may give rise to inference of abandonment causing break in continuity.
The long absence fact relates to whether mere unauthorised absence breaks the master-servant relationship under the continuous service definition.
The 81-month unauthorised absence grounds the holding that long unauthorised absence permitting inference of abandonment causes break in continuity.
The specific fact of long unauthorised absence triggers the issue of whether such absence legitimately causes break in continuity by inferring abandonment.

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly states that the meaning of 'continuous service' from Factories Act context has no material bearing, directly addressing the issue of whether Factories Act provisions should guide interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: As this Court has observed in Budge Budge Municipality v. P. R. Mukherjee 2 , the same words may mean one thing in one context and another in different context. This is the reason why decisions on the meaning of particular words or collection of words found in other statutes are scarcely of 1 1953 S.C.R. 219. 2 1953 1 L. L. J. 195, 198. much value when we have to deal with a specific statute of our own they may be helpful but cannot be taken as guides or precedents. Therefore, the meaning attributed to the words continuous service in the context of the Factories Act may not have a material bearing in deciding the point in the present appeal.
With this modification we confirm the award and dismiss the appeal.
e companytinuance is disrupted but it is difficult to hold that merely because an employee is absent without obtaining leave that itself would bring t

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly states that the statutory definition from IDA s.2(eee) cannot be automatically extended to the award, directly addressing the issue of its applicability.

anchor.surface_text: This definition is undoubtedly relevant in dealing with the question of continuous service by reference to the provisions of Industrial Disputes Act but its operation cannot be automatically extended in dealing with an interpretation of the words continuous service in an award made in an industrial dispute unless the context in which the expression is used in the award justifies it.
With this modification we confirm the award and dismiss the appeal.

edges.explanation: h3 provides interpretation of 'continuous service' in gratuity scheme, directly addressing i1

anchor.surface_text: Continuous service in the context of the scheme of gratuity framed by the tribunal in the earlier reference postulates the continuance of the relationship of master and servant between the employer and his employees. If the servant resigns his employment service automatically comes to an end. If the employer terminates the service, of his employee that again brings the continuity of service to an end. If the service of an employee is brought to an end by the operation of any law that again is another instance where the continuance is disrupted but it is difficult to hold that merely because an employee is absent without obtaining leave that itself would bring to an end the continuity of his service. Similarly, participation in an illegal strike which may incur the punishment of dismissal may not by itself bring to an end the relationship of master and ser- vant.

edges.explanation: Holding states long unauthorised absence inferring abandonment causes break in continuity, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: It may be a good cause for the termination of service provided of course the relevant provisions in the standing orders in that behalf are complied with but mere participation in an illegal strike cannot be said to cause breach in continuity for the purposes of gratuity. On the other hand, if an employee continues to be absent from duty without obtaining leave and in an unauthorised manner for such a long period of time that an inference may reasonably be drawn from such absence that by his absence he has aban- doned service, then such long unauthorised absence may legitimately be held to cause a break in the continuity of service.
With this modification we confirm the award and dismiss the appeal.
